captions.text:
The rainbow, as we know it, is Red, Orange,
Yellow, Green, Blue, Violet. ROYGBV. I'm ignoring
Indigo because, let's be honest. Indigo?

But where exactly is violet? Is it at the
end here? This dark blue? And what’s this

brighter light blue-green? Cyan, perhaps?
Why don't we say the rainbow is Red Orange
Yellow Green Cyan Blue? ROYGCB

Well, we actually do, and we’ve just forgotten.
When Isaac Newton originally observed a rainbow

of light split by a prism and made his labeling
of the colors as RedOrangeYellowGreenBlueIndigoViolet,

the thing he called “blue” was indeed
what we would now call blue-green, teal or

cyan – reminiscent of the color of the blue
sky. And what we now tend to call blue, Newton

called violet - as in, roses are red, violets
are blue. Dark blue. He only included indigo

in his fundamental "seven colors of the rainbow”
so that they would match the number of notes

of the western musical scale: Do re mi fa
so la ti… yeah.

Purple and magenta, as we know, don't occur
in the rainbow from a prism because they can

only be made as a combination of red and blue
light, and those are on opposite sides of

the rainbow – nowhere near overlapping.
So there’s no purple or hot pink in the

rainbow from a prism. Violet is there in the
“roses are red, violets are BLUE” sense,
but purple is not.

So then why do rainbows in the sky often look
like they have purple in them? I suspect sometimes

it's an optical illusion whereby nice deep
blues in small amounts surrounded by a lighter

color appear purplish to our eyes. HOWEVER,
sometimes purple and pink really ARE there

- because a rainbow is really a rain-disk:
each color of sunlight reflects back in a

bright-rimmed disc, all of different sizes,
which together add up to make a white disk

with a colorful rim. But because light is
a wave, interference from the raindrops themselves

actually gives each disk multiple rings - the
familiar outer ring is just the brightest.

The others are called "supernumerary rings"
and are the source of supernumerary rainbows

- the smaller the raindrops, the stronger
the supernumerary bows. And if the drops are

the right size, the first red supernumerary
ring can overlap significantly with the main

dark blue ring, and what do red and blue give?
Purple!

So as the saying goes, roses are red, violets
are blue, and purple in a rainbow is a supernumerary
hue.

comments.author: Haiko Van Der Leeuw

comments.text:
+Matt McIrvin "Red", "green" and "blue" are misleading names for the L, M 
and S cones. The L ("red") cone contributes to yellow as well as red 
opponent signals, the M ("green") cone contributes to yellow as well as 
green opponent signals, and the S ("blue") cone contributes to red as well 
as blue opponent signals, the last being the real reason why spectral 
violet is reddish blue.
http://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/IMG/opponent.gif
comments.author: djcbriggs

comments.text:
+Matt McIrvin "Hoax" was an overstatement, as I don't think he is actually 
aware of his mistake. The most likely explanations are that he is red-green 
colourblind, or that he has only seen photos of the spectrum, where 
spectral violet does come out as blue.
comments.author: djcbriggs

comments.text:
+Matt McIrvin thank you. You have given me quite a bit to look in to.
I've been experimenting with prisms, and I definitively get purpely and 
violetty colours, even on a single refraction.
I suppose that this is on the line of, seeing is believing.
Even if it's only trickery of the mind.
comments.author: Haiko Van Der Leeuw

comments.text:
...but I think the claim that we attribute purple to the rainbow because of 
the overlap of supernumeraries with the main bow is just this guy's 
personal hypothesis. Certainly in photographs of rainbows you can see that 
phenomenon, but it doesn't mean it's the origin.

I suspect all it is is that many people just assume, without trying the 
experiment, that you can stretch the saturated hues in the color wheel out 
into a line and identify that with the solar spectrum. I sometimes even see 
explanations of "ROYGBIV" that identify "indigo" with magenta, which is 
even more wrong.
comments.author: Matt McIrvin

comments.text:
...I'd read before that the "red" cones in our retina, sensitive to the 
longest wavelengths, have a small secondary peak of receptivity at the 
short-wavelength end that gives the very shortest-wavelength visible light 
a violet tinge. But the graphs of this that I've been able to find online 
are all over the place: some show this and some don't.

Of course, it could be happening at some deeper level in visual processing, 
or simply be a phenomenon of the names we give to colors.
comments.author: Matt McIrvin

comments.text:
+djcbriggs It's not a hoax, but I think he's somewhat overstating the case 
for the nonexistence of spectral violet; it's a matter of degree. The 
spectral color is, at the very least, a fairly bluish shade of violet. 
*Most* of the hues we call violet or purple, though, are non-spectral, 
along that magenta edge of the CIE horseshoe:

http://www.efg2.com/Lab/Graphics/Colors/Chromaticity.htm
comments.author: Matt McIrvin

comments.text:
+Haiko Van Der Leeuw Because the video's a hoax. Spectral violet (reddish 
blue) is not an "overlap".
comments.author: djcbriggs

comments.text:
It depends on what you call "violet". The violet in the solar spectrum is 
not magenta (pinky-purple); it's a bluer color. The sensation of magenta 
*only* arises through mixing of monochromatic hues.

That makes magenta different from the other secondary hues of light, which 
can arise either through mixing of primary colors, *or* through stimulation 
by a single wavelength. (There had to be some such color, since with three 
primaries the saturated hues form a wheel of colors, but the visible 
spectrum is a band with definite ends.)
comments.author: Matt McIrvin

comments.text:
LEDs are essentially monochromatic so if purple is a mixture of red and 
blue, how do purple LEDs exist (at about 400nm)? When I search for 
"spectrum of a prism" if see lots ending in purple. I suspect that 
depending on the source of "white" light that is split by the difference in 
velocities of light in the prism's optical media, that purple may indeed be 
the absent if the light is not the sun (e.g. incandescent or fluorescent) 
since they either don't have enough high energy spectra (incandescent) or 
that it's high energy spectra is frequency translated to lower frequencies 
(fluorescent). Admit it, you screwed up. You're human, right?﻿
comments.author: Art Mezins

comments.text:
If you look at the sensibility spectrum of the red cone receptor in your 
retina, you will see a peak at 560 nm and a small bump around 400 ,nm wave 
lenght. So at 400nm the light will excite blue cones and slightly red 
cones, that s why it apears purple. Below 400nm the light will apear dark 
blue and fade away.﻿

People who never give a balls about physics tend to forget that light is 
just a limited part of the radiation spectrum; from radio- to gamma rays or

the duality of light for a second here). Light is just that part of the 
wave spectrum that the eye can see.﻿

comments.author: Brandy Beck

comments.text:
Guys, you really need to look at an actual spectrum. You can look at the 
reflections on a CD if you don't have a prism. Unless you are red-green 
colourblind you'll see violet (reddish-blue) at the end of the spectrum. 
You don't see this if you rely on photographs because this short wavelength 
band doesn't affect the long wavelength (red) sensor of a camera. This 
ridiculous story that spectral violet is actually blue is starting to 
spread all over the internet!﻿
